content.html:
In this unit, students will:

  • Simplify radical expressions involving square roots.
  • Solve quadratic equations by taking the square root, completing the square, and using the quadratic formula.

To accomplish these unit-level learning goals, students will complete the following lessons and activities.

Lesson Number

Lesson Title

Associated TEKS

Unit 9, Section A Overview: Completing the Square

9.1

What Are Perfect Squares?

A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.2

Completing the Square, Part 1

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.3

Completing the Square, Part 2

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.4

Completing the Square, Part 3

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.5

Quadratic Equations with Irrational Solutions

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula. A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

Unit 9, Section A Quiz

Unit 9, Section B Overview: The Quadratic Formula

9.6

The Quadratic Formula

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula. A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

9.7

Applying the Quadratic Formula

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula. A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

Unit 9, Section B Quiz

Unit 9, Section C Overview: The Vertex Form Revisited

9.8

Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Vertex Form

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \((f(x) = a(x −h)^2 + k)\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \((f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c)\).

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry.

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.9

Using Quadratic Expressions in Vertex Form to Solve Problems

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \((f(x) = a(x − h)^2 + k)\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \((f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c)\).

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry.

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

9.10

Deriving the Quadratic Formula (Optional)

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.
